questions.q: What is the main purpose of an operating system?
options: To make the computer easier to use
To manage computer hardware and software resources
questions.explanation: An OS manages resources, provides an interface, and makes the system user-friendly.

questions.q: The kernel is:
options: The core component that runs at all times
A temporary program loaded at startup
questions.explanation: The kernel is the one program running at all times on the computer.

questions.q: Which component of a computer system provides basic computing resources?
questions.explanation: Hardware (CPU, memory, I/O) provides the fundamental resources.

questions.q: What does DMA stand for?
questions.explanation: DMA allows high-speed I/O devices to transmit data directly to memory.

questions.q: Which storage device is typically volatile?
questions.explanation: RAM loses its contents when power is turned off.

questions.q: Multiprogramming is designed to:
questions.explanation: It keeps the CPU busy by always having a job to execute.

questions.q: In symmetric multiprocessing (SMP):
options: Only one processor can run the kernel
questions.explanation: In SMP, each processor performs all tasks including OS functions.

questions.q: What is the purpose of an interrupt vector?
options: To store the addresses of interrupt service routines
questions.explanation: It is an array of pointers to the specific routines that handle interrupts.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT a function of process management?
questions.explanation: File compression is a file management or utility task, not a process management core task.

questions.q: Virtual memory allows:
options: Execution of processes not completely in memory
questions.explanation: It allows programs to run even if they are larger than physical memory.

questions.q: The bootstrap program is typically stored in:
questions.explanation: It is stored in firmware (ROM) so it is available immediately on power-up.

questions.q: Which of these is a real-time operating system characteristic?
questions.explanation: Real-time systems must process data and respond within fixed time constraints.

questions.q: In client-server computing, the server:
questions.explanation: The server waits for requests and provides data or services to clients.

questions.q: What is caching?
options: Storing data temporarily in faster storage
questions.explanation: Caching copies data to a faster storage system for quicker access.

questions.q: Which mode allows privileged instructions to execute?
questions.explanation: Privileged instructions can only run in kernel mode to protect the system.

questions.q: A trap is:
questions.explanation: A trap is caused by an error (like division by zero) or a user request for OS service.

questions.q: In a clustered system, high availability means:
questions.explanation: Clustered systems are designed so the service continues even if one node fails.

questions.q: Which is NOT a mass storage management activity?
questions.explanation: Compiler optimization is a development tool task, not a storage task.

questions.q: The mode bit is used to distinguish between:
questions.explanation: It indicates whether the CPU is running user code or kernel code.

questions.q: Open-source operating systems are characterized by:
questions.explanation: Open-source means the source code is public and can be modified by anyone.

questions.q: An operating system acts as an intermediary between users and hardware.
questions.explanation: This is the fundamental definition of an OS.

questions.q: Application programs directly control hardware without OS intervention.
questions.explanation: Applications must use the OS to access hardware resources safely.

questions.q: The kernel is the first program loaded when a computer starts.
questions.explanation: The bootstrap program loads first, which then loads the kernel.

questions.q: All operating systems have the same definition and components.
questions.explanation: Definitions vary; some include GUI/apps, others only the kernel.

questions.q: I/O devices and CPU can execute concurrently.
questions.explanation: Device controllers and the CPU work at the same time to increase efficiency.

questions.q: Main memory is typically non-volatile.
questions.explanation: RAM is volatile; it loses data when power is lost.

questions.q: Secondary storage is faster than main memory.
questions.explanation: Secondary storage (like HDDs) is much slower than RAM.

questions.q: Multiprocessor systems always have better performance than single processor systems.
questions.explanation: Performance depends on the application and overhead; it's not 'always' better.

questions.q: In asymmetric multiprocessing, all processors are equal.
questions.explanation: In asymmetric, one processor is the master and others follow instructions.

questions.q: Clustered systems share storage via a common bus.
questions.explanation: They usually share storage via a Storage Area Network (SAN).

questions.q: Timesharing systems require response time less than 1 second.
questions.explanation: Timesharing (multitasking) needs fast response to appear interactive.

questions.q: A program and a process are the same thing.
questions.explanation: A program is passive (file on disk); a process is active (executing).

questions.q: Multi-threaded processes have multiple program counters.
questions.explanation: Each thread in a process has its own program counter.

questions.q: Virtual memory eliminates the need for secondary storage.
questions.explanation: Virtual memory actually relies on secondary storage to store overflow data.

questions.q: File systems abstract physical storage properties into logical files.
questions.explanation: The OS hides disk hardware details and presents a file-based view.

questions.q: All storage devices need to be managed for optimal performance.
questions.explanation: Management (scheduling/allocation) is key for system speed.

questions.q: Protection and security refer to the same concept in operating systems.
questions.explanation: Protection is internal (between users/processes); Security is external defense.

questions.q: Distributed systems must use identical hardware components.
questions.explanation: Distributed systems are often heterogeneous (mixed hardware).

questions.q: Real-time systems prioritize meeting deadlines over throughput.
questions.explanation: Meeting time constraints is more important than the amount of work finished.

questions.q: Handheld systems have the same requirements as desktop systems.
questions.explanation: Handhelds have limited power, memory, and screen size.

questions.q: Peer-to-peer systems distinguish clearly between clients and servers.
questions.explanation: In P2P, nodes can act as both clients and servers.

questions.q: Web-based computing has made operating systems less important.
questions.explanation: The OS is still vital for managing the hardware the browser runs on.

questions.q: All operating system code runs in kernel mode.
questions.explanation: Some OS components (like system programs) run in user mode.

questions.q: System calls always return control to the user program immediately.
questions.explanation: Some calls must wait for slow I/O operations to finish first.

questions.q: A device controller has its own local buffer.
questions.explanation: Controllers use buffers to store data before moving it to memory.

questions.q: Polling is more efficient than interrupts for I/O handling.
questions.explanation: Interrupts are more efficient because the CPU doesn't waste time waiting/checking.

questions.q: DMA reduces the number of interrupts during data transfer.
questions.explanation: DMA sends one interrupt per block of data rather than per byte.

questions.q: Cache coherency is only important in single processor systems.
questions.explanation: Coherency is vital in multiprocessors so all CPUs see the same data.

questions.q: Spooling allows overlapping of input and output operations.
questions.explanation: Spooling stands for Simultaneous Peripheral Operations Online.

questions.q: User IDs are used for access control in operating systems.
questions.explanation: The OS uses IDs to determine what files or programs a user can access.
